The initial interview is a collaboration between a client and clinician. It establishes the assessment assessment context and defines the problem from a biopsychosocial framework by evaluating factors related to the presenting problem, including the history and functional effects of the presenting problem, social history, coping style, and personal strengths and weaknesses (American Psychological Association, 2020 ). During the clinical interview, clinicians develop diagnostic hypotheses and determine an assessment plan. Information obtained during the interview informs case conceptualization, recommendations, and treatment planning. Because clients vary widely in their presenting concerns and in their socialization to mental health treatment, the types of questions used in an interview will also vary. When considering the information contained contained in this chapter chapter , clinicians should keep in mind that the relevance of the content will depend on the client’s life stage (e. g., child versus older adult) and type of interview (e. g., psychodiagnostic, psychoeducational, neuropsychological, forensic). A broad scope of information is provided here, though the clinician should take care to individualize the approach approach in a manner relevant to the client’s primary concerns. Sample interview questions are provided throughout this chapter.
